And the final question would be the breakdown of risk-weighted asset by division? It would be helpful, say, if you could provide it to us. Thank you.

About the regulatory capital. As I've said, well, the – well, we try and monitor what's happening on the regulatory front. And indeed we had issued this first estimate one year ago, or more than one year already, of the – and at that time we were seeing 140 basis points for Basel 3. Now, as it stands now, we say 180. In that evolution, there have been a lot of clarifications of – and changes up and down, not only – and in particular, indeed, as you say, the insurance treatment that seems now to evolve towards the weighting of the capital invested in the insurance business. While at the time it was more about a deduction from the capital instead of additional risk-weighted asset.

So this has – we – at this stage, we are based on the – we have based our estimates on the so-called Danish compromise that is on the table for discussion at the European level. But we'll – this is the way we did it.
Okay. And just in term of weighting of the insurance capital charge, could you just give a number? Or no?
Weighting is, I think, 370% if I am right. It's the same weighting as a private equity business, because by definition, it's not listed. So I think it's 370%
Thank you.

In CIB I think the best way is look at the cost of the second half and not only quarter-by-quarter. And as I mentioned, the cost income ratio for the second half was 63% with the government losses; excluding the government losses it was 59%, that's the reason why I mentioned around 60%, which is I think a good level. And the third quarter was too low; we have expressed they were an exceptional provision if I remember that we took back. So globally, I think about 60% globally for the second half, which is not reliable.

Regarding your last question about the revenues of French Retail Banking, we should perhaps go to slide 53, if we can have it. And you can see that there is a sharp difference between the evolution of net interest margin in the fourth quarter, which remains strongly positive with 2.4%. And we could expect this evolution to remain positive in this year through the re-pricing actions I already mentioned. But the evolution of commissions has been negative, minus 2.7%, due to two main factors I mentioned. First, financial fees and this is strongly dependent with the situation of financial markets and due also to a new factor which will play a role in 2012, which is the diminution of bank card fees; this is a new regulation by the antitrust authorities. So, this is clearly the story for the fourth quarter, where we were a bit hampered by the evolution of fees. It's not a question of interest margins.
We'll take our next question from Anke Reingen from Royal Bank of Canada.

Hi, yes, Anke here from RBC, I just had three questions. The first is on CIB and the outlook on earnings. And I understand some moving parts but I just wanted to make sure that I'm thinking about it the right way. If I take first half affirmed 2011 pre-tax profit for the year and make the adjustments in Q4, take out the €1.4 billion of the revenue hit of (120:05) €450 million come to about €1 billion pre-tax profit per quarter. Is this like longer term the right way to think about it pre any pricing benefit?
And then I was wondering if, I mean, currently it still seems your equity is allocated at 7%. So will this increase to 9% or 10% over time?
And then on the €25 billion of delivered risk-weighted assets reduction, I just wondered, you say it's €5 billion from sales, but how much is this in risk-weighted asset terms?

And then lastly just on deposit trends in your sort of like core retail businesses, I was – I mean the volumes in French retail, BeLux and BNL came down quarter-on-quarter, and I just wondered if this is – like your strategy continues to be not to compete on price at the expense of losing deposits? Or is there some seasonality in here? Thanks.

Perhaps on the question of deposits in Italy. If you look at the figures, two elements. First, the evolution of deposits, at slide 56, is slightly better in the last quarter than it used to be for the whole year. So it's for us, a good sign that our policy of not entering the deposits war as aggressively as our competitors has been a good one.

The other element is that if you look at the evolution of the whole market, we remain in line with the whole market. We even slightly increased our market share regarding deposits. So it's, for us, a very good sign that BNP Paribas reputation and image and the quality of our customer relations helped us to keep our clients and deposits despite not offering always the most aggressive prices. So we are clearly committed to keep this policy; we think it's the right mix.

Just coming back to the previous person's question about the risk weighted assets per business. It's on page 89. Just to give you the – I did some percentage of €614 billion so just have the figures. And your first question. I missed your first question because of the.
What's the impact on the de-leveraging from CIB, if I understood well. I believe we've given all we could say about if it's impact. That's it.

No, I'm basically trying to understand all the moving parts. Because I mean, clearly is it right if I look about the future profitability of the CIB business, if I take 2011 pre-tax, add back the one-offs, take off the €1.4 billion revenue loss, add back the cost synergies and then I have about €1 billion pre-tax per quarter. I mean, I'm not trying to get guidance here, but is this the right way to think about it? Thank you.

We have no guidance concerning CIB because we have never given guidance concerning CIB business. Because as I mentioned, I repeat, I'm on old man, I've seen so many crises, so many volatility that I think it would be very dangerous to make anything, especially in this change of environment. You have to think that the competition is changing. We are – there are less competitors, there are – some competitors are in great difficulty. So it's very difficult to make the differentiation because between the global decrease in the revenue push and the fact that a lot of competitors are disappearing or decreasing their situation. Globally, I mentioned that the financing activity, we will see less revenues. You have all the figures; I don't want to comment anymore. It depends on the speed and the level of the repricing and so you will see that quarter-after-quarter.

And second, concerning the capital market activity, I repeat that BNP Paribas is well positioned compared to some competitors because we have very strong client business activities and not at all proprietary trading that we see that the clients work a lot with BNP Paribas. And so, we will see not at the end of the day but at the end of this year, at the end of 2013, that BNP Paribas will succeed after the crisis because BNP Paribas, as you know, is a growing company. We continue quarter-after-quarter to deliver revenues, we say what we make. And so there is no – let's say no sex in BNP Paribas. No, but we work – we are boring. So, no recovery, nothing, no specific problem, so – and you will see that quarter-after-quarter, so I have no further comments on that. Sorry to be boring.
We will now take our next question from Alex Koagne from Natixis. Please go ahead.

Yes. Good morning, everybody. This is Alex Koagne from Natixis. I just have two remaining question. The first one is on revenue loss in the CIB. From my understanding in your Q3, the €1.4 billion revenue losses was linked to the reduction in RWA of €30 billion. Should I understand that the $15 billion additional that you earned this quarter will not lead to any revenue loss?

The second one is on your dividend policy. Obviously you are becoming more let's say cautious since you are decreasing the level of the payout ratio and even offering an option for – to pay in strip. I'm just wondering what have definitely made you more cautious? I mean, what is the reason behind you becoming more cautious in arena? Thank you.
I didn't get the first question, so.
Yes.

I'll just take on the second one, dividend payout. We are 25%. There are only a limited number of banks that will have dividend this year. So even 25% should be considered as high because to pay a dividend you need to have a relevant earnings and profit capacity. What is the main driver behind this move is the fact that one of the main objective of the group is to strengthen the capital base, because we really want to be ready by year-end to enter in the new, I would say, paradigm for the bank industry from the first day at the right level, not having to deal with problems or any issues coming from the Basel.

So we want to turn the page, this will be done by year-end and this is why we are – we came to that conclusion that 25% is fair enough. If you compare this payout to other large banks, you can fairly understand that is, well, of the same magnitude. Most banks offer something in between 10% and 20%. And considering the fact that part of the dividend is going to be paid in share, 25% in the end, in line with what has been given by other large banks. So, this is some kind of an equilibrium, so there is nothing else; this is a balance between giving a dividend to the shareholders and the fact that the company need to be prepared as soon as possible. So nothing less, nothing more.

Thank you. Yes, on the first question, the RWA reduction in CIB will lead to €1.4 billion revenue losses. In your Q3, my understanding was that the revenue loss was linked to a €30 billion RWA reduction. As of today in CIB, the reduction will be €45 billion, which means that we have €15 billion more, and I was just wondering whether this will lead to any revenue attrition or not?

You – well, when we say risk-weighted asset, it's a risk-weighted asset or equivalent. And we don't exclude to have some kind of a sale of some part of the businesses, with some good reason, that would create capital with, you know...
Okay.
With the equivalent risk-weighted asset. And.
Okay, thanks.
And we'll take our final question today from Omar Fall from UBS. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon. I'm Omar Fall from UBS. Three questions please. Just the cost of risk rise in financing, still at a modest level at 28 basis points, can you give us some detail on whether these were just a few lumpy files? And what's the risk of you making the cycle worse here through your deleveraging in some of the industries you're targeting, like real estate finance, auto finance, et cetera?

Second question, just on the Fixed Income revenue, which was surprisingly strong, almost best in class in the quarter, up 6% Q-on-Q, can you give some additional color on how you manage this given the bias that you have to the European rates business and the deleveraging, given trading assets have decreased materially as well? I think you may have started answering that but I couldn't hear.

And then final question, somewhat of a philosophical one on the LTRO, but some of your German and Nordic peers have stated that the long-term benefits of staying away from it, reputationally, et cetera, outweighs the potential short-term P&L benefits for those banks that can manage it. So when you're thinking of the amount you may borrow going forward in the LTRO, do you feel any constraints on the total size that you'll borrow? Or for you it's a free lunch, the stigma's been removed and it doesn't matter? Thank you.

Sorry the sound is really bad. So I understood at least the last question about the LTRO. We see the LTRO as really a technical way of trying and bringing some liquidity into Europe. And so we have taken it as something that we could use. And we have no – there is no deal, or no hidden deal, or we do exactly what we want to with that LTRO. And the first thing obviously was to use it in order to stabilize the funding of our portfolios. We are using – if we look back at the slide, maybe number – the slide about the balance sheet, the total balance sheet that I presented a few minutes ago...

36. You see that, yes, the fixed income securities are above the line. And so they are majoritarily funded through short-term funding, as said here. So the LTRO for us was an opportunity to stabilize this short-term funding instead of bringing that kind of securities to the market in repos or sometimes to – the first LTRO is three months or six months – to an opportunity to stabilize that for three years, with a possibility to opt out after one year, so it's very convenient.

So we maintained by the way, in the €188 billion, the funds we got from the first LTROs, we maintained that at short-term funding because we see that as just a way to make sure that the short-term funding from the ECB is stabilized for three years, it's the way we look at it. It's not really more than that because it's just a kind of a way to fund the liquid assets we have. And that's it. So there is no other constraint on the LTRO. And I think that psychologically it plays a significant role because it showed that the ECB was ready to make sure that the market would work properly and it would take care of the market. And that's very important.

Okay, and one of your questions, the cost of risk at the level of CIB financing, probably we can move to page 49. Let's see, there is nothing in relation with the deleveraging, not at all. And if you look at the cost of risk, it is very low all along the year. So we have some slight increase in specific provisions at the end of the year, but this is not at all a trend.

The trend is the level, the average level of the year 2011, which is very low. And so there is nothing specific and nothing in relation with the deleveraging. What we can add is that, as we work a lot with large corporate and large institution, we don't see anything specific on our radar screen; there is nothing specific and so that's the reason why we constantly repeat that we don't see at the level of CIB any reason to see the cost of risk increasing in 2012.

So your first question or your second question, I don't remember, was, if I correctly understood, why are your revenues, let's say, so good in the first quarter on Fixed Income compared to some competitor? I don't know about the competitors. What I can repeat and constantly repeat is that we have a client business model and so the revenues are linked to the activities of our clients. So, let's say globally, it was not so good in the first quarter; as I mentioned, it will be much better in the first quarter of 2012.

So all in all, our client base, specifically on our domestic market but also in U.S. and in Asia, continued to exist in the first quarter and we have no specific proprietary trading and something like that. So all in all, we think it was not so bad but correct at the level of Fixed Income.
Okay. Thank you.
Okay. Thank you very much. Philippe will tell you a few words.

Yes. I would like to – yes, as we are all here today in London, I would like to – just first, two things are important because your interviewers are going to change indeed. First, I would like to introduce Lars Machenil, he is going to be my follower. So Lars is going to become CFO of BNP Paribas starting the beginning of March as was already said.

Second, I would like to give you a scoop. So Béatrice Belorgey will move into the group, so she will stop being your main correspondent in the Investor Relations as the Head of the Investor Relations team. Béatrice, well, came in 2005 in the team and became head of the team in 2008. So she spent, I would say, three relatively good years and five, six and seven and four relatively bad years, the crisis years, so she went through everything. I think she made a great job, very great job, so I guess you will have your own opinion, I guess, but, well, we think that she made a very great job at the time where the disclosure tremendously increased and the demand for information and the pressure on Investor Relations team increased considerably.

She was extremely dedicated to you. I think you – well, you know that you can give her a phone call at any time in the day, even in the night, in the weekends, everywhere. This summer, again, she spent the month of August not – well, she was supposed to be on vacation but she worked almost every day I think in trying to answer to some worries of the market. She – well, she had the good knowledge of the market before coming to Investor Relations team having worked in the past in the Dealing Room I mean – and in the Structured Products, selling structural product and building structural product. And she is – her professionalism I think is very, very big and she has always been, I think, very – well, trying to provide you with all the information you wanted to have within the disclosure that is – that has the borders, as you know; so if there are borders, we – she – nobody is allowed to go over. But within those borders, I think she was really trying to do her best in order to provide you with the information.

So she will move back to her well business job, I would say. She's the private banking. You may know that she was coming from private banking and she will go back to private banking as the Head of the French Private Banking, so very important position in the bank. So she had a lot of fun, I think, but it's time for another challenge.

So she will be replaced by Stefan Devaniak (140:38), maybe you could stand up as well. So Stefan has been working with BNP Paribas for, well, for 20 years around. So he's an old chap of BNP Paribas and he worked in different areas of the group, he knows the group very well. Recently he was more in CIB and very recently while he was just – he's leading the position of Head of Leveraged Finance Europe, so he knows a lot these financing businesses of CIB. And so I'm sure that his experience, all his experience is going to help him in his new position.
So I wanted to take this opportunity, she will – he will take his new position in March, mid-March, but we wanted to tell you now, because we are here.

So thank you very much, Béatrice, and great success in the private bank. Béatrice will join the group of the top 100 executive of BNP Paribas by year-end. So this is like the 9% Basel 3 ratio; this is one of our targets. Thank you very much for attending the presentation.
